metadata.metaValue:
The resultion of the geometry passed here controls 
the number of starting rays.

To visualize large numbers of rays,
the following is recommended: 

Viewport:
A color management LUT such as ACES RRT
X-Ray mode
AA has high as it will go
Black background

On this node: 
Tiny size
energy_as_size on

Energy exponent of 1.0 is physical(ish), lower 
values exagerate the intensity of weak reflections
and transmissions.

Ray traces through a dielectrics, computing reflection and transmission, and visualizes the result. 

This is an example of building an iterative ray tracer in Bifrost using geometry queries. It can also be used as an intuition-building tool about how ray tracing works.

Since you're here, I assume you want to know how this ray tracer works. 

We start with a batch of rays. These are stored in a points geometry and composed of position, 
(ray origin), normals (ray directions), energy, color, and a hit boolean. 

Each iteration of ray tracing depth is stored as a new points geometry. The last point cloud in
the array is the next generation of rays to trace. For example:

 * Finished rays (depth: 0)
 * Finished rays (depth: 1)
 * Finished rays (depth: 2)
 * Finished rays (depth: 3)
 * Next rays to trace (Will be: depth = 4)

In this loop, we first take the last point cloud, and trace it. We update and whether or not the 
rays hit and hit positions. 

We evaluate our "shader". A shader's job in this system is to create new rays. This one creates 
new rays for reflections and transmissions, and divides up the incoming energy between them. 

After this, we've collected our point clouds and can draw those as rays.
